conclusion: To solve this problem, we need to analyze the forces acting on each of the hemispherical bodies A, B, and C. We will use the principles of static equilibrium, which state that the sum of forces and the sum of torques acting on a body must be zero.
Body A is a hemispherical body placed on a rough horizontal ground.
Body B is a hemispherical body placed on a rough horizontal ground.
Body C is a hemispherical body with a smooth outer surface placed between A and B.
All three bodies A, B, and C are in a state of rest, with A and B just touching each other and no force acting between them.
The radii of A, B, and C are all R, and the coefficient of kinetic friction between A, B and the ground is μ=√3/6.
The maximum static friction is considered equal to the sliding friction, and the gravitational acceleration is g.
Identify the forces acting on each body.
Body A has weight WA = mg acting downward.
Body A has normal force FA exerted by the ground upward.
Body A has frictional force fA exerted by the ground horizontally.
Body B has weight WB = 2mg acting downward.
Body B has normal force FB exerted by the ground upward.
Body B has frictional force fB exerted by the ground horizontally.
Body C has weight WC = mg acting downward.
Body C has normal forces NCA and NCB exerted by A and B respectively.
Body C has frictional forces fCA and fCB exerted by A and B respectively.

premise: Since C is in equilibrium, the sum of forces in the vertical direction must be zero.
Since C is in equilibrium, the sum of forces in the horizontal direction must be zero.
